string.text: Army Load-Bearing Vest
Load-Bearing Vest
A load-bearing vest designed for carrying essential ammunition and personal emergency medical supplies.
A belt pouch for carrying various small items.
Electronic Notebook
A reworked old smartphone turned into an electronic notebook by the technician Vergas.
Sleeping Bag
A lightweight sleeping bag. Waterproof. This model combines the comfort of a blanket-style bag with the high thermal insulation of a mummy cocoon.
Artist’s Sketchbook
A sketchbook of a deceased artist, filled with drawings and travel notes.
Army Flask
A flask with a screw cap on a chain. Made of food-grade aluminum. Comes with a protective cover. Designed for convenient carrying of liquids.
Decoder
A homemade device for breaking into electronic door lock systems and extracting the keypad code matrix.
Belt Bag
A handy bag for storing a small number of minor items. Commonly used by stalkers as a reserve emergency stash.
Glass in a Holder
A glass found in the Sanatorium. Clearly old-fashioned.
Mug
A mug found in the Sanatorium.
Cup
A cup found in the Sanatorium.
Grail
A goblet found in the Sanatorium. Looks like tea was brewed in it more than once...
Weight with a Mug
A weight found in the Sanatorium. A full pood. How did a mug get embedded into it like that? Damn Zone!
Beer Mug
A beer mug found in the Sanatorium. Clearly been through an anomaly.
Skis
Old wooden skis with soft felt-boot bindings and bamboo poles. Don’t glide at all.
Oh right, I found some kind of mug. Crawled all over the entire sanatorium...
Well I’ll be... Nice! Let’s see it.
You take this mug. I’m sick of hauling it around.

And you weren’t too lazy to lug all that weight, Marked One. The mug isn’t mine, and I don’t know the weight either... But you know, you moved me, Marked One. You didn’t spare the time or effort, crawling through some ruins just to please an old man you barely know. Hand the thing over. I’ll keep it as a reminder of your good deed.

Thanks for the trouble, Marked One, but no hard feelings. It’s not mine... But you know, you moved me, Marked One. You didn’t spare the time or effort, crawling through some ruins just to please an old man you barely know. Hand the thing over. I’ll keep it as a reminder of your good deed.

A fine little thing, but not mine. Use it yourself... But you know, you moved me, Marked One. You didn’t spare the time or effort, crawling through some ruins just to please an old man you barely know. Hand the thing over. I’ll keep it as a reminder of your good deed.

Sorry, but that’s not what you were supposed to find. Maybe you’ll get lucky next time... But you know, you moved me, Marked One. You didn’t spare the time or effort, crawling through some ruins just to please an old man you barely know. Hand the thing over. I’ll keep it as a reminder of your good deed.

Don’t recognize it. Someone else’s thing... But you know, you moved me, Marked One. You didn’t spare the time or effort, crawling through some ruins just to please an old man you barely know. Hand the thing over. I’ll keep it as a reminder of your good deed.

Some kind of grail. You didn’t find it in a church, did you? Head still aching? Clearly not mine... But you know, you moved me, Marked One. You didn’t spare the time or effort, crawling through some ruins just to please an old man you barely know. Hand the thing over. I’ll keep it as a reminder of your good deed.
Here, take a look. Must’ve been one hell of a quake at the sanatorium if it got embedded into a weight like that...
Here. A beer mug. Clearly been through an anomaly. You can barely even see it...
That’s not a cup, it’s a glass. But it’s got a holder.
Here, a mug like any other. Clearly someone drank tea from it.
Here it is, a little cup. Careful — porcelain. Fine work.
Not quite a cup, but they clearly had tea with it.
Oh! That’s mine! Hand it over, we’ll carve it out of the weight.\nAnd special thanks for not selling it to anyone.
Mine, my favorite! Holds as much as a samovar.\nAnd special thanks for not selling it to anyone.
My little glass! I remember nicking it on a train once... Accidentally.\nAnd special thanks for not selling it to anyone.
That’s the one, dear to my heart. You did me a real favor, Marked One.\nAnd special thanks for not selling it to anyone.
A collector’s item. That’s what I used to drink tea from at the sanatorium.\nAnd special thanks for not selling it to anyone.
There it is, my imperial goblet!\nAnd special thanks for not selling it to anyone.
Well then, take it and enjoy!
I’ll give this to you, Vergas… a bit later, I will…

Thank you, Marked One. At least I’ll have some kind of keepsake. Of my past life, or of your good deed — all that matters is that it warms the soul.\nAnd this is for you. Been saving it, so to speak, for old age, but for you — no regrets.
Well damn… And what do I need skis for? It’s May.
Nope, I don’t need a gun like that. Keep it.
Don’t need a sleeping bag — extra weight.
Thanks, I already have one. Don’t need a second pair of binoculars.
A battery’s a good thing, but I’ve got nowhere to put it right now. Sorry.
I’ll manage without that belt.
I’d take the container, but it’s too heavy. Keep it.
I don’t use that kind of ammo. No thanks.
Keep the repair kits. You need them yourself.
These medkits are too weak. Got any army or scientific ones?
Don’t need matches right now. A lighter would be better.
Nice armor, but mine’s better. I’ll pass.
Don’t need this. Field rations give me heartburn.
Vodka’s a good thing, but not right now.
Grenades are kinda weak. Got any anti-tank ones?
Don’t need antirads. I’ll treat myself with vodka instead.
Don’t need those “cat’s eyes”. Heard they make your kidneys fail.
How do people even drink this? Won’t even go down. Vodka’s better.
Canned food again... No, thanks.
Hunting? No need.
The best sausage is a sock full of money. Wanna trade for that?
You shouldn’t have passed on that. It’s a good piece.
A sleeping bag’s a solid thing. You’ll regret it later, when it’s too late.
Eh… that optics is German, you know.
A battery… That battery’s worth its weight in gold.
Just so you know, belts like that don’t lie around on the roadside.
Could’ve dropped it off in Stas’s stash, saved it for better times.
You’re a strange one, Marked One. You could trade that for anything you want at the Bar.
True enough. You’ll come crawling back for repairs anyway.
Medkits like these are a real rarity around here.
Look at what you’re asking for. Gasoline’s in short supply these days.
Wouldn’t say so myself, but suit yourself.
Agreed. This is nowhere near a NATO field ration…
Up to you. Drink vodka then — surprise your liver.
Maybe you’d rather I hook you up with a gun?
A decent option, but antirad’s more reliable. In my opinion.
Your loss. That’s good chemistry. And everyone’s liver’s still intact so far.
Right on the mark. But sometimes a can like that saves your life.
As you say. Canned food tastes like crap, but at least it doesn’t spoil.
That’s where you’re wrong. Tasty, and it won’t go bad either.
You’ll earn it yourself. All I can offer is a sock.
Thanks. Hope this comes in handy.
You’re welcome.
Alright, I’m off.
Hey now, my friend, only the Zone knows how long you’ll be walking her paths. You’ll probably ring in the New Year somewhere around here.
Don’t jinx it, Vergas. But fine — I’ll take it.
There we go.
Got it. I’m not an idiot.

Vergas, I can’t get your story out of my head… the one about you lying paralyzed in that local Sanatorium, then the emission putting you back on your feet. You also asked me to look for your cup, remember? It’s all strange. What if there are sometimes special, “healing” emissions?

“Healing,” yeah right. It only worked like that on me — for the others lying there, it was hell. And why it happened to me that way, who knows. And the cup… you know, I’m starting to think maybe there was no “special” cup at all. Just an ordinary hospital one. Or maybe I made it up entirely, just so life wouldn’t feel so scary. Just to have at least some proof of my past life.

Yeah, I get it. I’d dig with my bare hands just to learn anything at all about my own past. By the way, about your cup — I’ve been to that Sanatorium more than once, but I never came across any dishes. Except maybe three-liter jars.

Really? That’s a shame. You’re the one who took care of the burer that settled there, right? The youngsters have been talking… You’re a good man, Marked One. You didn’t forget my request, and you even did a good deed that helped everyone. Ah, to hell with it! I’d been saving something for a rainy day, but you need it more. Here, take this — a gift from me.
Well, old man… I don’t even know what to say. I didn’t expect this. Thank you.
